task.title: Troubleshooting Physical Issues
task.shortdesc: If resetting your router doesn't work, there may be some physical issues, such as a faulty power source, hardware damage, or the router being in the wrong environment.

step.cmd: Check that the power outlet for your router is working properly. You can do this by plugging a different device into the same outlet and checking that it's charging.
step.info: Note: If the router's indicator lights are off, it could be a sign that the outlet or the power cord aren't working.

step.cmd: Inspect the router, modem and cables for signs of physical damage. This can include tears or kinks in cables, dust build-up in the router vent, and cracks or dents in the router or modem.
step.info: Note: If there's a dust build-up in your router vents, you can try removing it with compressed air or a cotton swab. If any of the hardware is damaged, the best thing to do is replace it!

step.cmd: Check the placement of your router. If your router isn't in a central location, is too close to other sources of electricity, or is obstructed by materials like concrete or metal, it may need to be moved to receive a better connection.
step.info: Note: It also helps to put your router in a cool area where it isn't being hit by sunlight. This helps reduce over-heating and dust build-up!

step.cmd: Check your device's connection to see if the issue has been resolved.
